title: Before 1 September 2021, will Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan sign an agreement governing the filling of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) reservoir?
preds: The political tension between the regions and the general backlash it is all ready facing will stop this

Given the current internal instability of Ethiopia, President Abiy Ahmed has and is likely to use the GERD to create a "rally around the flag" dynamic as the country is at risk to disaggregate along ethnic lines. This internal threat is likely to persist for a long time and hence GERD negotiations are likely to remain inconclusive for that period. Equally, the filling of the GERD is likely to take several years. Maintaining a certain level of tensions and external existential threat is equally useful for Egypt's al-Sisi's and his regime.
Very little time left, multiple parties.

Why is Egypt shocked that Ethiopia has started to refill the dam?  This fake righteous indignation is ridiculous, after they were given a timeline for starting to fill for the last SIX years.  Egypt and Sudan now want UN involvement, but Ethiopia is saying "NO", preferring African union resolution to the impasse.  Any and all sides will continue to drag this out, as the water level rises behind the dam.  Abiye has other things to worry about in Tigray that are taking away attention from the GERD.  AP report (link below) is saying Sudan and Egypt think they can get a deal done in 6 months.  Staying at 7%, since Ethiopia isn't in agreement.
https://apnews.com/article/middle-east-africa-business-egypt-sudan-bb3e5fb7a6f60b20c4f7ca5d8cf2eb2a
No, the conditions for an agreement do not exist. There must be more sacrifice before that happens.
The UN appears to be getting more involved and pushing for a resolution between parties

Al Ahram analysis reveals some of the complexities regarding the GERD, Egypt's desire to (re) escalate the issue to the UN Security Council, which is causing some problems among its allies, and the revelation of who the Saudis are backing. Read it here https://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/50/1201/416279/AlAhram-Weekly/Egypt/GERD-Back-to-the-Security-Council.aspx

Not sure Ethiopia has any intent of getting into an agreement.  They are too busy with internal conflict.  Yes a letter the the UN might indicate pressure, but sept is only 3 months away and it will take time for the letter, representations from the UN to Ethiopia and then négociations.  And is an agree text for the agreement even out there in a form Ethiopia would even consider? Seems very unlikely we can get through all of those stage by 1 Sept, even if Ethiopia does engage.
https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/sudan-asks-un-security-council-meet-over-ethiopias-blue-nile-dam-2021-06-22/
Ethiopia's government is side tracked by conflict in Tigray is unlikely to want to appear compromising.

Lowering the probability based on time passed. I've lost count of the number of times any of the three countries have wanted help negotiating a solution, and then changed course.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-12/egypt-addresses-letter-to-un-security-council
Too short a time and too much political uncertainty
Sudan are still not on board...the agreement in principle is there...Egypt are a bigger Military force but receding and the the other countries are playing for time as Ethiopa is growing Military.

Until the African governments accept outside help (from the US or UN), I don't see this being resolved in a timely manner.  Maybe as Ethiopia beings the second-stage filling?  There are two issues at play here.  First, we've told Africa to solve African problems with African solutions.  The second is that over the last four years, the US pulled back from all of its international engagements, favoring isolationist policies instead of diplomacy.  Now when we raise our hand and say "We'll help you!", everyone is going to tell us to get lost.  In a phone call with al Sisi, Biden said he was committed to a diplomatic solution...could have been lip service.  "President Biden acknowledged Egypt’s concerns about access to Nile River waters and underscored the U.S. interest in achieving a diplomatic resolution that meets the legitimate needs of Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia."  Forecasting down for passage of time.
https://www.voanews.com/middle-east/us-again-looks-help-resolve-ethiopian-dam-dispute
https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/05/24/readout-of-president-joseph-r-biden-jr-call-with-president-abdel-fattah-al-sisi-of-egypt-2/
The discussions have been going on for a long time. It will likely require UN pressure / pursuasion to reach an agreement. Other conflicts are center stage right now.

Statement by Ethiopia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs "However, Egypt and Sudan rejected the draft demanding the role of observers to replace that of the three countries and the AU. The two countries followed an approach that seeks to undermine the AU-led process and to take the matter out of the African platform. They also stalled the resumption of the negotiation by rejecting a draft communiqué that contained the deliberations of the two-day meeting. Rather both countries attempted to obstruct the process.
[...]
The second-year filling of the GERD will be carried out as scheduled pursuant to the Declaration of Principles (DoP). In this context, Ethiopia expressed its readiness to facilitate data and information exchange on the filling of the dam. The positions contesting the filling of the dam ahead of the conclusion of an agreement has no basis in law and contravenes Ethiopia’s inherent right to utilize its natural resources."
https://www.ethioembassy.org.uk/press-release-on-the-trilateral-negotiations-on-the-gerd/ Ethiopia's Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed recently also stated the country does not want to do any harm to either Sudan or Egypt, but at the same time is doing so by continuing to plan filling the GERD during the upcoming rainy season. EDIT:
https://www.theafricareport.com/86352/ethiopia-egypt-the-impressive-feat-of-engineering-that-is-the-gerd/
https://www.theafricareport.com/86356/ethiopia-gerd-what-would-push-egypts-sisi-to-resort-to-force/

https://www.africanews.com/2021/04/16/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-talks-fail-to-break-nile-dam-deadlock/ Water supply is a delicate subject and difficult to agree, and difficult to stop or intervene on the ground to change things when not in your country.  As the article says, “talks are going nowhere”

The children aren't playing together nicely these days, so back to zero for a while. 
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/7/egypt-warns-ethiopia-of-potential-for-conflict-over-blue-nile-dam  I forget who suggested this, but the solution to any negotiation deadlock is to sequester the parties in a small room with no food, water, loo, telephones, radios, televisions, internet access, or chairs. They'd get it sorted out in a very pronto time frame.  Alas, this will never happen.
while it is in the news due to Egypt's recent threats, we are entering the dry season and there will not be impetus to drive towards an agreement until the rains begin again

Just an update on where we stand on arbiters: The UN is ready to step in and aid negotiations.  Sudan has formally requested the help of the UN, US, AU, and EU.  Annnddddd...Ethiopia (who doesn't want outside mediation) rejected the plan.
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-03/18/c_139817785.htm
https://www.voanews.com/africa/sudan-requests-un-us-eu-help-resolve-dam-conflict-ethiopia
https://thearabweekly.com/ethiopia-rejects-sudan-call-outside-mediation-dam-dispute

Perhaps with a renewed U.S. arbitrator, we will see some movement.  Ethiopia is going to start filling the dam in round two during the rainy season.  They have the upper hand right now in negotiations.
https://www.globalconstructionreview.com/news/biden-changes-tack-ethiopias-grand-renaissance-dam/
https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2021-03-05-could-new-mediators-finally-resolve-the-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-dispute/
Less time left for the challenge results in lower probability.
Most likely. It would be nice if they just agreed on something at least semi-agreeable before it happens regardless in the shadow of something else.
-12, Coming down on passage of time and what seems like no progress.

It seems that the negotiations are greatly complicated by the fact that there are three parties to it instead of the "usual" two. It looks like that currently they do not even have a common understanding on the roadmap to a negotiated agreement. https://www.arabnews.com/node/1791031/middle-east
Rising tensions between Ethiopia and Sudan over the Fashqa triangle make the chance of a deal on the GERD virtually impossible. (https://twitter.com/criticalthreats/status/1360344363348480002)

Ethiopia has a big internal problem now. So its attention is not focused on the dam and they might resist the outside pressure in the near future. Also so far all 3 countries struggled to find a common ground.

Multiple rounds of talks have failed and Ethiopia is already filling the reservoir without repercussions so it will likely become even more difficult to reach an agreement. The Ethiopian government's attention is currently focused on the Tigray conflict further decreasing the chance an agreement. Lastly, Ethiopia and Sudan are in the midst of a border dispute which will only make both sides less willing to compromise on other issues. https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20210130-ethiopia-accuses-sudan-of-occupying-its-lands-fighting-by-proxy-for-third-party/
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-28/ethiopia-moves-artillery-to-sudanese-border-after-deadly-clashes

The 3 countries had already met in January 2020 before the covid to sign an agreement and it didn't work (source: https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2020/01/16/barrage-sur-le-nil-l-egypte-l-ethiopie-et-le-soudan-esquissent-un-compromis_6026068_3212.html). There is no date for the meeting, and the covid is still there.
And the crowd forecast is 5%

No moves by any of the big players in the last two weeks.  Sometimes I feel like African politics is the slowest game of chess ever.  Things should start to pick up as we get closer to the summer and the dam really starts to fill.  No change to my forecast.

the conflict between Sudan and Ethiopia about the border city Fashqa makes an agreement more unlikely
http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/50/1203/399228/AlAhram-Weekly/World/Sudan-vs-Ethiopia-The-luxury-of-war.aspx

Sudan is pushing for more international arbitration.  I read that to be more U.S. involvement, now that there is a new administration.  While Antony Blinken did give a nod to the Horn of Africa during his confirmation hearing the other day, the GERD did not come up as a topic.  He sounds more interested in negotiating a settlement of the Tigray dispute.  That being said, if there is an increase in negotiation and a reversal of humanitarian aid to back to Ethiopia, this may be one of the conditions that must be met in order to receive the funds.
Sudan looks for alternatives so it seems they don't believe in a sucessful agreement. https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/sudan-looks-for-alternatives-as-nile-dam-talks-stall/2114336

Failed again.  But I'm still holding out hope!  There is probably going to have to be an outside arbiter if all three countries can decide on who that will be (AU, UN, US, etc). If they can't even decide on who should be at the meetings, to begin with, this will likely take the next 8 months. We will likely see a sense of urgency from both Sudan and Egypt as the dam is filled and the consequences of filling the reservoir start to be felt downstream.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ethiopia-dam-sudan-egypt/three-way-talks-on-ethiopian-dam-reach-new-impasse-idUSKBN29F0J7
https://www.wionews.com/world/talks-on-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-fail-again-356124

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/1/10/sudan-voices-frustration-as-latest-nile-dam-talks-stall Stuck again, it seems.  Most negotiations of this sort look like a 16-year-old kid trying to drive a stick shift: Quite a lot of lurching and stalling before any progress happens.  Still, progress usually does happen, but for such purposes as this Q (and driving a stick), timing is everything.
Too many wonkish, weasel word ambiguities.  This question ought to be re-worded to say "binding agreement"  and-or "non binding agreement.
Continuing "differences in dialogue" has resulted in a breakdown of negotiations again.  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/1/10/sudan-voices-frustration-as-latest-nile-dam-talks-stall

Sudan is pushing for talks to resume and be negotiated by the end of January.  That's a tight timeline, and unlikely to happen.  As we've seen in the past these talks tend to breakdown, there is a period of stubborn obstinance to come back to the negotiating table (strong-arming, power-brokering, and posturing).  I'll reassess after Sunday's meeting (10 Jan) on whether or not there will be tripartite negotiations going forward and how much involvement there will be from the UN, AU, and South Africa.
https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/ethiopias-dam-on-river-nile-is-triggering-water-conflict-in-east-africa-7133441/
https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-sudan-deeply-concerned

Reported by Le Monde in Paris, alleged recurring spisodes of sabre rattling between "Sudan"  and Ethiopia are just another factor that will slow down the process... link in French, here https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2020/12/30/l-ethiopie-et-le-soudan-a-couteaux-tires-pour-le-controle-d-une-zone-frontaliere_6064842_3212.html

They can at least agree on need to agree to talks. Ethiopia playing for time.
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1766066/middle-east

Reliance on the AU will likely increase the chances of a negotiation happening, however, it may not get done before the 1 Sep deadline of this question.  But the three countries all continue to agree that working towards an agreement is in the region's best interest.
https://menafn.com/1101282952/Sudan-agrees-to-continue-negotiations-on-Grand-Ethiopian-Renaissance-Dam&source=30

Ethiopia doesn’t want to internationalize the issue, but Sudan calls for help from the AU and Egypt turned to the EU and UN for supervision. This makes an agreement in the near future more unlikely.
https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20201208-sudan-refuses-to-internationalise-renaissance-dam-crisis/

This is a great summary article of what's going on in the region right now:
https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/12/03/ethiopia-needs-united-states-honest-broker-blue-nile-dam-dispute-gerd-egypt-sudan/
I would expect as the new administration comes in, and we see a shift in foreign policy to more liberal institutionalism, the US may reverse course in this part of the world, playing the broker for negotiations between Ethiopia, Egypt, and Sudan.  However, the US is facing many different competing interests and this may not take top priority, even on the African continent.

The region is historically unstable and even recent event have made the situation even worse. Even though Egypt depends for 90-95% of it's water on the Nile. (https://dailynewsegypt.com/2019/09/13/egypts-land-is-95-desert-country-depends-by-95-on-nile-waters-says-abdel-aty/) negotiations are not the only way to solve this problem. (sabotage, desalination) Also international negotiations are slow and the three countries are still discussing about framework for further negotiations. (https://africa.cgtn.com/2020/11/05/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-disagree-on-methodology-for-nile-dam-talks/)  
Recently Sudan boycotted further negotiations because they wouldn't lead to anything. (https://news.cgtn.com/news/2020-11-22/Sudan-boycotts-faltering-talks-over-Ethiopia-s-mega-dam-VCoy1LWNnG/index.html)

I could imagine that this could also lead to an agreement just between Ethiopia and Egypt.

Egypt is attempting to get Sudan on board! Al Sisi traveled to South Sudan for the first time in his presidency.  This would seem to indicate how important shared cooperation between both countries is (and not just for the GERD).
New point on the timeline as of Thursday:  June 2021 is the first time the dam will be turned on and start generating power.  It would behoove all three countries to come to an agreement either before or during that time.
Can we all agree that President Salva Kiir's cowboy hat is amazing?
https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/94734/South-Sudan-agrees-with-Egypt-on-necessity-for-reaching-legal

The African Union (through South Africa as arbitrator) has managed to bring all three countries together to resume talks, despite the political unrest in Ethiopia.  While Egypt is pushing for negotiations, Sudan has claimed that the negotiations are permanently on hold based on a lack of mediators (which it needs to strengthen its position).  A tri-national agreement will likely take a lot of time and involve more parties, including the EU and US, so the 1 September 2021 deadline is not wholly unexpected.  Per the below article: 
"Sources concerned with the Nile water issue confirmed that the current negotiations face a number of challenges, including the difficulty of agreeing on a mechanism for resolving disputes stipulated in the Declaration of Principles signed between the leaders of countries in 2015, and the careful coordination and exchange of information regarding the operation of water dams in Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia, which may lead to major technical problems in the absence of a rapid and compatible mechanism for coordination and exchange of information between the two sides."
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1766066/middle-east

The GERD takes away balance from a system of Nile river states and unilaterally empowers Ethiopia to force lower Nile countries like Egypt and Sudan to accept Ethiopia as a regional power over fear for strategic water cuts. This is unlikely to happen as it would be a sharp cut in sovereignity and independence for the growing nations. A consensus solution is therefore unlikely to be in place without lenghty deliberations to possibly give Ethiopia the chance to display their good intentions in action during periods of drought and water shortage.

It seems as though things in Northern Ethiopia continue to disintegrate as the Tigray conflict widens, now spilling over to Eritrea.  If Ethiopia can clamp down on internal dissidence, Abiy may be able to come to the table with Sisi and whichever provisional government is in charge of Sudan.  Ethiopia has been courting the African Union to arbitrate and deal, while Egypt has engaged the European Union to aid negotiations. However, it seems increasingly unlikely that all three countries will sign an agreement, and it may be two bi-lateral agreements instead (there has been no news of Ethiopia meeting with Sudan, which seems to have been marginalized in this whole process).
https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/93943/EU-to-play-positive-role-in-file-of-Ethiopian-Renaissance
https://www.npr.org/2020/11/13/934241830/what-to-know-about-ethiopias-tigray-conflict

Egypt is building a massive desalination plant, and this is seen as an admission that they are not going to get Ethiopia to come to an agreement. Ethiopia has no real incentive to commit to allowing a certain amount of water through.

Current domestic policies in Ethiopia have stabilized the country (Tigray elections, COVID-19, cooperation with Beijing).  Ethiopia has continued to fill the reservoir based on nationalist identity and energy dependence, despite Egyptian and Sudanese objections, and ignoring U.S. cuts to aid (instead choosing to depend more on China).  
https://moderndiplomacy.eu/2020/11/09/how-prime-minister-abiy-looking-to-change-ethiopia/
https://intpolicydigest.org/2020/11/02/facing-up-to-realism-will-egypt-bomb-the-dam/

It's water warfare plain and simple. Look at all the defense spending some of the bonehead World Bank water projects rolled out during the MacNamara era drummed up.  Most of the common folk in the three nations, and man-made influencer nations like "South Sudan", and the rabble rouser newbie states that brand and rebrand themselves in the Balkanized Horn of Africa get angry, get polarized, engage in asymetrical warfare, but do not know what an existential threat is because it is a term that the Western world policymakers have used to define them so that they (the "West" can maintain a "policy edge".  Existential threat is a meme that is becoming a "weasel word."  Wonk stuff.  Have you ever heard Joe Biden, Donald Trump, Mike Pompeo use the phrase?  Barack Obama probablly has. How many Americans know what it means.  Does the winner of the big Scripps National Spelling Bee" know...  Its getting trite.

While U.S. denial of foreign aid has sent a strong message to the Ethiopian government, they are now facing a conflict in the Tigray region that will occupy a lot of bandwidth.  Since there is currently no dispute mechanism in place for tripartite talks, the states will probably remain in a stalemate.  Compounding the issue is COVID-19, stifling the ability for the three states to meet and negotiate.
https://www.theafricareport.com/44337/ethiopia-egypt-sudan-trust-linkage-and-cooperation-can-end-dam-dispute/
https://theconversation.com/suspension-of-us-aid-to-ethiopia-is-yet-another-example-of-trumps-disregard-for-africa-146460
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/africa-in-focus/2020/08/05/the-controversy-over-the-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam/

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/11/2/sudan-egypt-and-ethiopia-resume-nile-mega-dam-talks
Well, they've started talking again, so I'm bumping up my estimate by 50%.  However, 9 is still not a big number.   The outstanding issues are fairly complex and so far intractable.  Stay tuned.

It's difficult, even if they talk.
"Egypt, which depends on the Nile for about 97 percent of its irrigation and drinking water, sees the dam as an existential threat." https://www.arabnews.com/node/1756971/middle-east

There is water
At the bottom
Of the ocean

Talks are resuming, but Egypt appears to have a history of making extreme demands with regard to the dam. Seems like a good sign that talks are resuming but the recent history doesn't make prospects look good. Talks resuming: https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/27/sudan-to-resume-talks-with-ethiopia-egypt-over-nile-dam
Overview of relations between the countries up until now: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Ethiopian_Renaissance_Dam#Impact_on_Sudan_and_Egypt

Trump suggesting that Egypt blow up the dam has probably had an adverse effect on the negotiations also with the US cutting off foreign aid.
It would appear that the dam is being filled by natural causes i.e. rain in June through September that was shown by satellite images after the talks had broken down.
Egypt and the Sudan depend on these waters from the Blue Nile and control of the water supply downstream gives Ethiopia significant power both in the political and energy sense.
Video talks are between the three states are commencing as reported  of 27th October.
Another concern over the resolution of this disagreement and obvious lack of trust is the involvement of China and its campaign to increase its influence in Africa.
The Presidential election in the US will perhaps have an effect on the continuing talks with a potential change in US foreign policy (or not).
The dam will take 5-15 years to fill to its capacity and the longer period the better to offset any dramatic effects. However, a build-up of silt as filling begins, will present social issues.
At this time an agreed resolution, within the next 12 months, that is agreeable an advantageous to both sides with increased US/China interference seems unlikely. https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/ethiopia-reacts-to-trumps-reckless-nile-dam-remarks/2018086
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-54416424
http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/389207/-.aspx
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-19089-x
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53416277
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/27/sudan-to-resume-talks-with-ethiopia-egypt-over-nile-dam
https://www.max-security.com/reports/strategic-analysis-reprecussions-of-chinese-investments-in-the-nile-river-basin/
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-05/18/c_137189350.htm
https://www.aucegypt.edu/news/stories/egypt-and-ethiopian-renaissance-dam

If Trump doesn’t get re-elected, maybe he should run in Egypt? Picture his noggin on the Sphinx. A pyramid for his domicile. And a fight with Ethiopia.
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-54674313

This is a 'slow motion' conflict. The reservoir is filling up over a period of years during the rainy season. Ethiopia's maximum control over the Blue Nile water will not occur for several years, so there is limited political pressure to resolve this soon Need to consider Biden administration's relationships with Egypt, Ethiopia & Sudan... There is likely to be a resetting of US-Egyptian relationships, in the wake of Trump who was supportive of the Egyptian regime. Biden's focus on global democracy is likely to put pressure on Egypt Sudan has just recently been removed from the US's list of state-sponsored terrorism, which it has been on for 27 years. This will enable it to access foreign & military aid. Sudan's removal from the terror list was designed to encourage it to normalise relations with Israel, which has been announced today. A new US administration is likely to continue to support Sudan, as it endeavours to become a fully-fledged democracy https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/20/world/africa/Sudan-terror-list.html https://allafrica.com/stories/202010090857.html https://english.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2020/7/10/biden-would-drastically-change-relations-with-saudi-egypt-adviser

Egypt's domestic issues are the primary focus. Additionally, Egypt doesn't have any leverage and Ethiopia sees significant resources. They've had this conversation for over a decade without an agreement. Without a third party involvement, I don't see any movement on this.

This seems unlikely. Ethiopia has no incentive to make promises to Egypt and Sudan. The only incentive would be the risk of losing U.S. aid and the risk of war. It is likely to remain at an impasse until a drought forces the issue. However, half of Ethiopia is without electricity. The dam seems more important than US aid. If Ethiopia promises a certain amount of water through the dam, it could jeopardize electricity during drought years. Reduce by 1 pt/2 months unless something happens like scheduled talks or drought.
While it would benefit each country to have an agreement in place, currently it seems less than likely there will be an agreement reached by 9/01/21.

This was suppose to be done already but the differences are great and compromise does not seem to be an option right now.  The political situation in Ethiopia makes any concessions to Egypt and Sudan hard to imagine.  It may be more beneficial for Egypt and Sudan not to agree to anything and wait out the possible turmoil in Ethiopia.
